text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

text: I feel this could have been clearer about dfferent whale feeding behaviour. Baleen whales are mainly eating krill at the surface so not adding to krill, apart from gray whales which scoop up mud from the sea floor. Rorqual and toothed whales are eating bigger stuff, including diving for it, and bringing that up the water column to fertilise algae and so krill. That is the important part for the pelagic or open ocean zone. The video might also gave mentioned the importance of 'whale falls' in delvering carbon to the deep ocean, which is thought to have had an unexpectedly large impact historically

text:
Do not hate Japanese. Most Japanese do not approve nor support the killing of whales for any purpose.
But, too many have a passive attitude towards this issue do not to engage in opposing killing whales.
The issue is the complicity of the government and the fishermen communities. These have cooperated for years to build a large, modern fleet of ships for the purpose of killing whales. Entire communities depend on this insane practice and the government has no intention of stopping them as they bargain connivance for political votes.
Hating all Japanese is a mistake as this may unnerve those who are now silent, bringing them closer to the nationalist-right wing politicians who support this practice.
The rage must be against the Japanese government.
Whales are not the only species Japanese are threatening but tuna also is endangered by Japanese fishermen acting with the complacency of the government.
Maybe tuna (and all fish, in general) needs more help with us stopping eating sushi.
And don't forget Chinese: killing millions of sharks every year for the belief that a dull soup will prevent them from having cancer.

text: Great video! I would say that the same argument holds not only for whales but for all fish in the sea at their own scale. When we fish, we mine the atoms that make up all the marine biomass and this poses a limitation as to how many animals can be present in the sea. With less animals, the nutrients are not dispersed and remobilized into biomass efficiently and falls to the bottom. The role of animals is underestimated in the IPCC reports as their actions are not taken into account in the climate models so far. The overall logic is that the physics determine the climate on its own when animals could help us maintain good living conditions on Earth.

text: Dear Chris, Your two videos of the wolves and whales are the most inspirational short introductions to the awesome 'web of connections' that exists quietly and generally unknown all around us that I have encountered while teaching sustainability/environmental issues for over 25 years. Thank you SO much. I have just shared the Wolf video with over 100 friends by email and intend to use it in my course this Spring to have the student's create 'mind maps' or 'a web of connection' diagram in the first class. I would also like to add them to my website: www.environmental-ed.com  I am SO joyous that so many people have watched these videos (over 22 million)...ahh...change is slowly coming...With HOPE, and HUGS, Chris (Summerville) in Japan.

text:
¬†@BitOveRate¬†
¬†I think I see what you mean, it's like why some people go to crime because their jobs didn't hold down the bills, and they couldn't get into college. Or why some people eat mcdonalds because it is cheap, or appears more affordable than fresh fruits and vegetables- but eventually, both not only contribute to a less desirable and enjoyable planet, they pay a personal and costly price for their decisions, out of the quality of life that they live.
I agree that providing alternatives, and advertising available alternatives to the general public awareness, would be a great way to curb unethical practices.
author: Hannah Patten

text:
Yeah i wouldn't necessarily say all whalers and criminals are bad people per se. but it is possible that out of desperation these same people are driven to do something against their will. I would say there is no justification in whaling commercially. However in some parts of the world that are remote islands, they dont have the privilege of choosing which to eat and which not to. For example the Kula Ring a whale feeds entire villages and the meat is readily trade able for other things. They need a varied diet to be healthy as well which is why they enjoy a variety of different meat. Though even if done for survival they may still stockpile the whale meat and if given the chance may kill more in order to trade for later.¬†In other parts for example the Faroe Islands its done for sport, in a yearly tradition. Some people might see it as a part of their nations identity but it only really seems to be a sorry excuse so they can justify them continuing to do it. Somethings in our heritage are to be proud of but not everything in my opinion. Somethings we need to use our own personal judgement on, instead of accepting it because of a long standing tradition.
Its a tough issue but i definitely dont think there is a need for commercial whaling and certainly not for sport.
Ultimately if there was a drop in demand for whale products than it would also become less profitable and might make the whalers look elsewhere for profits.
author: BitOveRate

text:
¬†@BitOveRate¬†
I had no idea there was tradition behind killing whales in addition to habit. Yes, since consumer and producer are two sides of the same coin, it is also helpful to educate consumers so that they do not buy whale meat when it is available, or if it is traditional perhaps to eat it only for special occasions or once a week instead of daily.
Do you know of areas where there has been success in declining the consumption of whale meat?
author: Hannah Patten

text:
Yeah, it is pretty sickening, what is worse is that it is a part of Denmark that does it, not some third world country, so they should know better..
There are spots that are restricted to kill whales, but some will still whale them even still. Partly because the locals have no way of reporting them because of their limited technologies. So that is another issue.
¬†Something else to worry about is whales being captured, younger whales are worth more alive than dead, and being separated from their pod it causes a lot of distress. Places like Seaworld have been criticized for that, they put them in with whales they don't know/belong with, which causes them to lash out at each other.¬†
If you look at the case of Northern White Rhinos, they have a contingent of bodyguards watching them around the clock. They also dyed their horns a pink color and added toxins into it that keep people from using it as medicine. The same may be true with whales some may see it as medicinal. Ultimately there needs to be an effort to debunk the medicinal value of it, or at the very least find an alternative that is just as effective without killing whales. its a bit harder to get armed guards following around a whale b/c you'd need shifts of scuba-divers or submarines. which would be costly. Maybe we could take notes from Dr. Evil and attach a laserbeam to some whales and let them deal with the poachers themselves.¬†
Im not totally sure if there are areas where consumption has went down, i think areas where there are less whales than before the consumption may go down, but it is hard to say if it is because of a shifting attitude towards it or not.
author: BitOveRate

text:
¬†@BitOveRate¬†
¬†I will definitely keep that information in mind. One way of staying involved in government for me has been through signing petitions. Recently a petition for saving 8 beluga whales from being captured for a marine aquarium in the united states was posted. I always think about what it is I am signing, and I thought to myself, "Well it is 8 so that would make a pod, that way they aren't lonely. And as a kid going to an aquarium, that actually caused me to care about those creatures out in the wild. So I won't sign, because it seems like it's ultimately for a good cause. The kids that see those belugas will want to save them, or have an opportunity to care- rather than never seeing them and therefore not really caring if they all die off in the wild." However, if as you say whales are usually picked out from pods, that would cause a lot of distress, and that causes me to reconsider signing that petition. Perhaps it would be better for a group to start a breeding program for whales and dolphins etc. for aquariums, preferably from ones that are already in aquariums, so that new generations can be taken from there rather than the wild. That way, pods will not be broken up, mothers will not lose their children, and wild whales can continue to propagate- which is exactly what is needed. And in the meantime, new generations of children will grow up with "cool experiences" of animals they saw on the other side of the glass, and care about protecting the ones that are out in the wild. It's definitely a difficult topic, though.
author: Hannah Patten

text: ¬†@Hannah Patten¬†¬†Yeah petitions are a good way of showing support. Id need to look more into the situation but im not for keeping whales in an aquarium in most circumstance. My understanding is Their dorsal fins end up collapsing after being in a tank for long periods of time. You just cant mimic the same conditions as the ocean. Confinement is still stressful to them regardless of being with their pod or not. being confined to a small area could make them irritable, look at prisons for instance. the truth is no killer whale has ever killed a human in the wild but in captivity there have been plenty of fatalities. They need a varied diet not just fish which is fairly common with aquariums they deserve the peace and quiet away from humans on a constant basis. Only circumstance would be if they are injured and incapable of returning to the wild or they are trying to prevent them from going extinct. There arent enough as it is in the wild, and it certainly doesnt help the ecosystem with them in a tank. Ultimately there are other alternatives to educating people on the importance of stewardship of the environment. A TV show where they can see them in their own habitat would be a better alternative. I have never been to an aquarium with whales, but still have come to understand their plight without the need of seeing them up close and as much as i want to see them in person I dont. Any aquarium that is profiting off of the animals probably doesnt have their best interest at heart, thats just my personal opinion though.
author: BitOveRate

text: ¬†@Hannah Patten¬†¬†Not to mention capturing them could stress them out drastically. I can only assume an animal instinctively thinks once you captured them you are going to kill them, they dont expect you to take them as a pet and if you did keep them in a holding tank who is to say they arent living in fear that one day they will get killed out of the blue. ¬†
author: BitOveRate

text:
¬†@BitOveRate¬†
Aquarium owners could definitely do more to help their animals feel at home and be healthy. For me, it was always the in-person experiences. The big night skies, the mountains, the strange animals i met or saw up-close, that helped me realize there is more in this world than my house and my neighborhood. That there is a big ocean and other lands with people and animals on the other side of the world, that the world is really big and I'm really small but that I play a part in it just like everyone else. I was fortunate to live in a family that took me to planetariums, aquariums, camping etc. so that I could enjoy the experiences and have a chance to understand the big picture. If experiences like that could become more mainstream, it could help people help the world.
author: Hannah Patten

text: ¬†@Hannah Patten¬†¬†its great that you want people to learn about nature the same way as you have. I just think it could be done without the need to put whales in captivity. I have went to planetariums, zoos and camping when i was younger, but at the time i was probably too young to really appreciate what i saw. It wasnt until later that i truly had an appreciation and respect for nature. It all depends really once kids are teenagers going to the zoo is all of a sudden boring unless you are taking a girl on a date. my friends were concerned about drinking, smoking and playing video games, it just wasnt a concern of theirs at the time. There is a certain point when kids grow out of that mentality. I stopped taking the world around me for granted but it wasnt because i went to a planetarium or zoo it was because I made a conscious decision to keep a more positive mindset and value all life around me no matter what species. I think people need a more positive attitude when growing up, it should be encouraged to care about the environment and not frowned upon which often happens with some groups of kids.
author: BitOveRate

author: dont eat animals

text:
Shark find soup is NOT a Japanese delicacy.  It is a Chinese delicacy. Those two cultures are very different, and just confusing them would be a major offense to both Japanese and Chinese people. 
By confusing things like this, we are making both Chinese and Japanese people LESS likely to listen to conservation issues that Western people are concerned with. We need to educate ourselves before we try and educate others, so that we can gain the respect of the people of these cultures. Without their respect, they aren't going to listen to us, and then the conservation issues will be lost among cultural ignorance.

text:
MegaFauna Too;
The late Pleistocene to Holocene boundary shows a prestigious pedogenesis, the loess‚Äìpaleosol sequences of the central and northern Great Plains record a broad peak of high effective moisture, a pedogenesis we can emulate with the bio-remediation techniques we advocate as the only economic way to reverse climate change..
The new research concerning the ecologically limiting effects of Phosphorous caused by the loss of the Mega-Fanua means we have never seen the true vigor that forest & grass lands could be. That what we now see as "pristine" systems are but a shadow of their primary production potential. The Pleistocene megafauna extinctions resulted in large and ongoing disruptions to terrestrial biogeochemical cycling at continental scales, switching off this natural nutrient pump by a massive 98%. The megafauna diffused sodium inland and also reduced concentrations in plants near the coast. [1]
(There is a whole parallel literature developing in the marine literature, with deep diving megafauna playing a key role in nutrient dispersal in the oceans).

[1]

The legacy of the Pleistocene megafauna extinctions on nutrient availability in Amazonia
http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v6/n9/full/ngeo1895.html?WT.ec_id=NGEO-201309

text: Hunting down wild animals at the top of the food chain, including whales, is a huge ecosystem mistake, given they are a vital part of Nature's re-cycling system for the basic chemicals of life.¬† The crash of ocean plankton numbers over the last 50 years needs a compelling explanation. Phyto-plankton are the basis for all¬† ocean life. The best things that we could do now, to avoid a complete global life systems crash, is outlaw all killing of any and all large ocean animals, and cut global carbon dioxide emissions. Attempts to compensate for our failures to do this cannot be fixed with geo-engineering.¬† Nature makes human geo-engineering (for sustainability) look very stupid.

text:
¬†@Hugo Galdos¬†¬†I have two contrasting views on humanity and it's impact on the natural world. ¬†
My first is that I agree with your opinion of our negative impact a result of humanities extremely high numbers. There is a maximum weight limit to how much biomass any ecosystem can support. ¬†Our population takes a large percentage of this biomass. Surprisingly the insects and especially the ants take a higher percentage than we do..
My other opinion is we are also caretakers of nature and deserve to be recognized for that. ¬†Would another organism that reaches our height grow as many flower gardens, or set out as many bird feeders as we do? ¬† We can't answer this but the idea that we don't know how we compare gives weight to placing a positive tag on our abilities as much as a negative. ¬†One thing that gets overlooked in all this is that Where humans live you will always find trees being grown. ¬†The forests have thinned but they cover more land as we have spread out.¬†
